Caroline-College/Optional-Rules---Distre.title: Optional Rules - Distress Points (DSP)
Caroline-College/Optional-Rules---Distre.content:
Optional Expanded Sanity Rules for Call of Cthulhu
Note: These rules are optional and will be discussed during Session Zero. They are designed to enhance the horror experience in long-term campaigns without incapacitating characters through excessive Sanity loss.
These rules were heavily inspired by the work Apostol Apostolov at  Chaosium Call of Cthulhu 7th Edition House Rules
For details on making characters see Player Guide
Introduction
The Expanded Sanity Rules introduce a new mechanic called Distress Points (DSP) to add psychological depth and realism to our game. Like standard Sanity Points (SAN), which decrease as characters encounter supernatural horrors, Distress Points start at a maximum value and decrease as characters face stress from realistic, non-supernatural threats. This allows characters to handle man-made horrors and stressful situations without immediate risk of madness.
Distress Points (DSP)
What Are Distress Points?

Distress Points represent your character's mental resilience to stress from non-supernatural situations, such as tough decisions, resource scarcity, or dangerous environments.
Every character starts with DSP equal to their POW (similar to how SAN is calculated).

Losing Distress Points

Non-Supernatural Encounters: Non-supernatural horrors cause DSP loss instead of SAN loss. This would replace the traditional sanity roll for these mundane encounters.
Stressful Situations: When facing non-horrific, but still stress situations, DSP checks may need to be made.
SAN Rolls: Making a sanity roll, by definition, is caused by a situation that is stressful. You lose a a DSP every time a sanity roll is made; pass or fail.
Voluntary SAN Damage: You can always choose to take SAN damage instead of losing DSP, but not the reverse.

Effects of Distress Points

Above Half DSP (more than half of your maximum DSP): You remain composed; your hidden traits are under control.
Equal to or Below Half DSP (half or less of your maximum DSP):

Begin to show minor signs of stress linked to your Dark Trait.
Each time you lose 5 or more DSP at once, roll against your current DSP. If you roll equal to or less than your DSP, you experience a Breakdown for 1d4 rounds.


Equal to or Below One-Fifth DSP (one-fifth or less of your maximum DSP):

Your behavior is noticeably affected by your Dark Trait.
Breakdowns last longer (1d10 rounds), and the Keeper may suggest actions for your character.


At Zero DSP:

You suffer a Complete Breakdown.
The Keeper may take control of your character until DSP is recovered.



Maximum DSP

DSP cannot exceed your starting value (POW). Rest and recovery can help you regain lost DSP up to this maximum.

Example of a Breakdown
Scenario:
Maria, an investigator with a starting POW of 60, starts with DSP = 60. Her Dark Trait is Paranoia, which she keeps hidden from the rest of the team.
Events Leading to the Breakdown:

Initial Stress:

Maria and her team are exploring an abandoned asylum.
She encounters realistic but disturbing graffiti and unsettling noises.
Over time, she loses 20 DSP, reducing her DSP to 40.


DSP at Half Maximum:

Since her DSP is now at 40 (which is two-thirds of 60), she remains composed.


Further Stress:

The team finds a room with detailed accounts of past tortures (non-supernatural).
Maria loses 15 DSP due to the distressing content, bringing her DSP down to 25.


DSP Falls to Half or Less:

With DSP at 25 (less than half of 60), she begins to show minor signs of her Dark Trait (Paranoia).
She starts questioning the intentions of her teammates subtly.


Triggering a Breakdown:

Suddenly, a realistic but horrific trap is sprung, causing Maria to lose 10 DSP at once, dropping her DSP to 15.
Because she lost 5 or more DSP at once and her DSP is below half, she must roll against her current DSP (15).

She rolls a 22, which is above her DSP.
Breakdown Triggered: The Breakdown will last 1d4 rounds (let's say she rolls a 3).





During the Breakdown:

Behavior:

For the next 3 rounds, Maria's paranoia takes over.
She becomes convinced that one of her teammates is sabotaging the mission.
She might accuse them openly, refuse to share information, or even act defensively if approached.


Keeper's Role:

The Keeper reminds Maria's player of her Dark Trait and suggests actions that reflect her heightened paranoia.
The player can choose how to role-play these suggestions within the confines of the Breakdown.



After the Breakdown:

Maria's DSP remains at 15.
She regains some composure but still shows signs of stress.
The team may notice her odd behavior, and she might need to find ways to recover DSP.

Dark Traits
What Are Dark Traits?

Dark Traits are hidden aspects of your character's personality that emerge under stress.
They add depth to your character and provide role-playing opportunities.

Selecting a Dark Trait

Choose a Dark Trait during character creation. It should remain secret from other players but not the keeper.
Examples include traits like paranoia, obsession, aggression, or compulsiveness.
Your Dark Trait influences how your character behaves as DSP decreases.

Revealing Dark Traits

As DSP decreases, subtle behaviors linked to your Dark Trait begin to surface.
Under severe stress or during Breakdowns, these traits may dominate your actions.

Managing Distress

Rest and Relaxation:

Short Rest: Resting for at least an hour in a safe, comfortable environment restores 1d10 DSP. This cannot be repeated until at least one point of DSP has been lost.
Extended Rest: A full day of rest restores 10 DSP (may be repeated as needed).


Composure Attempts:

POW Roll: Attempt a POW roll to compose yourself. If your current DSP is at or below half maximum, the roll is of Hard difficulty.
Success: Restores 1d4 DSP during danger or 1d6+1 DSP when safe.


Assistance from Allies:

Another character can use a Psychology roll to help you recover.
Success has the same effects as a successful POW roll. These cannot be used in conjugation. But if one fails, the other may be attempted.


Indulging in Manias:

Engaging in a personal mania restores 1d6+1 DSP.
Requires a Sanity roll; failure results in 1 SAN loss.



Pacing Stress Loss

To keep gameplay smooth, DSP losses can be accumulated over a scene and applied at the end.
This minimizes interruptions and maintains narrative flow.
Immediate DSP losses may still occur during sudden shocks or critical moments.

Increased Impact of Phobias

If your character has a Phobia, encountering its trigger doubles any DSP losses.

Purpose of These Rules

Enhanced Role-Playing: Allows for deeper character development as hidden traits surface under stress.
Balanced Horror Experience: Maintains the horror atmosphere without quickly incapacitating characters through massive Sanity loss.
Long-Term Campaign Suitability: Ideal for extended play, where character arcs and psychological journeys are explored over time.

Conclusion
Please consider how these rules might enhance your gaming experience. They aim to add psychological realism and depth to our campaign, offering new challenges and role-playing opportunities without overwhelming your character with Sanity loss. We'll discuss these rules in detail during Session Zero to ensure everyone is comfortable and understands how they will be integrated into our game.

List of 50 Example Dark Traits
The following are example dark traits; others are possible. Please discuss your choice with the keeper before finalizing your selection.
Dark Traits Table
| Trait              | Description                                                            | Under Distress Effect                                                                      | Breakdown Result                                                                                |
| ---------------------- | -------------------------------------------------------------------------- | ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| AGGRESSIVE         | Physical action and violence are your solutions to every problem.          | You display bouts of verbal aggression and may intimidate allies who challenge your decisions. | You are unlikely to restrain yourself from combat until any perceived enemy is neutralized.         |
| MARTYR             | You feel overwhelmed by responsibility for others.                         | You become less concerned with your own well-being and focus entirely on your allies' needs.   | You're willing to sacrifice yourself for a greater goal or the survival of others.                  |
| COWARD             | Fear dominates your actions.                                               | You become pessimistic and sarcastic, openly expecting the worst outcomes.                     | You panic and flee, even if it means abandoning your friends in danger.                             |
| EGOTIST            | Your primary concern is your own well-being and survival.                  | Your decisions prioritize your needs over others.                                              | You place your safety above everything, even denying help or betraying allies.                      |
| SADISTIC           | You derive pleasure from others' discomfort.                               | You may enjoy causing harm or misfortune to feel better.                                       | You pursue actions that cause maximum harm to enemies, even if it jeopardizes plans or allies.      |
| PARANOID           | You believe others are constantly scheming against you.                    | You see coincidences as evidence of conspiracies.                                              | You're convinced immediate events are part of a grand plot and take drastic action to counter it.   |
| PSYCHOPATHIC       | You disconnect from others' emotions and needs.                            | You focus solely on your goals, unable to communicate intentions or feelings.                  | You lose the ability to cooperate, resolving problems only on your own.                             |
| ANNOYING           | You have habits that irritate others, like excessive talking or fidgeting. | These habits intensify, helping you cope with uncertainty.                                     | You struggle to concentrate, taking extra time and lacking focus.                                   |
| DEPENDENT          | You seem independent but rely on others when stressed.                     | You cling to others for guidance and protection.                                               | You're incapable of making decisions without someone telling you what to do.                        |
| MEGALOMANIAC       | You have an insatiable need for power and control.                         | Feeling weak causes you anxiety and frustration.                                               | You'll stop at nothing to gain power, even embracing dangerous paths.                               |
| CURIOUS            | Your thirst for knowledge overrides caution.                               | You can't resist uncovering secrets, even risky ones.                                          | You're compelled to experiment with newfound knowledge, often recklessly.                           |
| FIXATED            | You focus on repetitive activities to escape stress.                       | You feel compelled to continue these activities.                                               | You fixate on one activity as a source of comfort, resisting attempts to stop.                      |
| LOUD               | You express emotions vocally.                                              | You can't keep your voice down and openly share your thoughts.                                 | You make a scene, yelling or ranting, potentially wasting valuable time.                            |
| ZEALOUS            | A strong belief or moral code anchors you.                                 | You obsess over this belief and become anxious if it's challenged.                             | You feel your belief is under attack and will defend it fiercely.                                   |
| CATATONIC          | You withdraw inward to cope.                                               | You find it hard to speak and may shut down.                                                   | You halt actions, adopt a neutral posture, and become nearly mute, passively resisting interaction. |
| BURDENED           | You carry deeper troubles than most.                                       | Your underlying issues surface, affecting your behavior.                                       | Combine behaviors from two traits, intensifying your reactions.                                     |
| COMPULSIVE LIAR    | You habitually lie, even without cause.                                    | Your lies become elaborate and hard to maintain.                                               | You create a false reality and insist others accept it.                                             |
| MANIPULATIVE       | You influence others for personal gain.                                    | You resort to deceit and exploitation.                                                         | You may manipulate allies into dangerous situations for your benefit.                               |
| OBSESSIVE          | You fixate on thoughts or ideas.                                           | Obsessions dominate your actions.                                                              | You can't focus on anything else until satisfying your obsession.                                   |
| PESSIMISTIC        | You expect the worst outcomes.                                             | Your negativity affects group morale.                                                          | You're immobilized by hopelessness.                                                                 |
| RECKLESS           | You take unnecessary risks.                                                | You disregard safety measures.                                                                 | You engage in dangerous actions without considering consequences.                                   |
| JEALOUS            | You envy others' successes or possessions.                                 | You undermine or sabotage others.                                                              | You attempt to take what others have by any means.                                                  |
| DECEITFUL          | Honesty isn't your policy.                                                 | You lie to protect yourself or gain an advantage.                                              | You can't tell the truth, even when necessary.                                                      |
| ARROGANT           | You believe you're superior.                                               | You belittle others and ignore advice.                                                         | Overconfidence leads you to make poor decisions.                                                    |
| CONTROLLING        | You need to be in charge.                                                  | You become domineering.                                                                        | You attempt to control every aspect, causing conflict.                                              |
| STUBBORN           | You refuse to change your mind.                                            | You reject others' ideas.                                                                      | You insist on your way, regardless of consequences.                                                 |
| IMPULSIVE          | You act without thinking.                                                  | You make hasty decisions.                                                                      | You take immediate action without consideration.                                                    |
| ENVIOUS            | You desire what others have.                                               | You fixate on others' possessions or status.                                                   | You might steal or sabotage to level the field.                                                     |
| APATHETIC          | You lack interest or concern.                                              | You disengage from situations.                                                                 | You become unresponsive to events around you.                                                       |
| NARCISSISTIC       | You have an inflated sense of self-importance.                             | You demand special treatment.                                                                  | You believe only you can solve problems, dismissing others.                                         |
| MASOCHISTIC        | You find satisfaction in your own discomfort.                              | You may self-sabotage or take unnecessary risks.                                               | You engage in self-destructive behaviors.                                                           |
| UNTRUSTING         | You doubt others' intentions.                                              | You suspect betrayal from those around you.                                                    | You isolate yourself, refusing help.                                                                |
| GLUTTONOUS         | You overindulge in pleasures.                                              | You seek immediate gratification, neglecting duties.                                           | You binge excessively, ignoring consequences.                                                       |
| IRRATIONAL         | You abandon logic and reason.                                              | You make illogical decisions.                                                                  | You cannot be reasoned with, acting unpredictably.                                                  |
| VINDICTIVE         | You hold grudges and seek revenge.                                         | You dwell on past slights.                                                                     | You focus solely on settling scores, regardless of cost.                                            |
| FRACTIOUS          | You're irritable and prone to conflict.                                    | You pick fights over minor issues.                                                             | You become uncooperative and disruptive.                                                            |
| OBSTINATE          | You're unyielding and inflexible.                                          | You resist any change or compromise.                                                           | You become a barrier to progress and group harmony.                                                 |
| SUPERSTITIOUS      | You believe in omens and rituals.                                          | You rely on superstitions to make decisions.                                                   | You refuse to act without a 'sign' or ritual.                                                       |
| WORKAHOLIC         | You're addicted to work.                                                   | You immerse yourself in tasks to avoid issues.                                                 | You neglect health and relationships, focusing only on work.                                        |
| HYPOCHONDRIAC      | You fear illness excessively.                                              | You misinterpret symptoms as serious ailments.                                                 | You believe you're critically ill, hindering your actions.                                          |
| RESENTFUL          | You hold onto past wrongs.                                                 | You bring up old grievances.                                                                   | You act out against perceived offenders, even if unwarranted.                                       |
| INDECISIVE         | You struggle to make choices.                                              | You're paralyzed by options.                                                                   | You're incapable of deciding without external intervention.                                         |
| GUILT-RIDDEN       | You're burdened by remorse.                                                | You fixate on past mistakes.                                                                   | You may confess to wrongs, real or imagined, distracting from current issues.                       |
| SCHADENFREUDE      | You take pleasure in others' misfortunes.                                  | You may cause or amplify others' failures.                                                     | You actively create situations where others will fail.                                              |
| COMPULSIVE CLEANER | You need cleanliness and order.                                            | You focus on tidiness over urgent matters.                                                     | You stop everything to clean compulsively, ignoring pressing issues.                                |
| ESCAPIST           | You avoid reality through distractions.                                    | You retreat into fantasy or indulgent activities.                                              | You detach completely from reality, becoming unresponsive.                                          |
| CONTROL FREAK      | You micromanage every detail.                                              | You can't delegate tasks, overwhelming yourself.                                               | You try to handle everything alone, leading to burnout.                                             |
| PROCRASTINATOR     | You delay tasks habitually.                                                | You avoid responsibilities, causing delays.                                                    | You refuse to act, even when action is critical.                                                    |
| PERFECTIONIST      | Nothing meets your standards.                                              | You obsess over minor flaws.                                                                   | You're immobilized by the impossibility of perfection.                                              |
| EMOTIONLESS        | You suppress your feelings.                                                | You become detached and indifferent.                                                           | You can't empathize, making cold, calculated decisions without regard for others.                   |

Caroline-College/Player-Guide.title: Player Guide - Caroline College
Caroline-College/Player-Guide.content:
House Rules for Caroline College - An Early 1980's Call of Cthulhu Campaign Setting
These house rules are designed to enhance your gaming experience by:

Increasing character survivability regarding sanity loss.
Providing more development options for characters.
Keeping starting character abilities aligned with their status as beginning college students.
Adding more depth to characters through enriched backstories and mechanics.


Disclaimer
This is a game of horror. Some themes may be disturbing to some players. Players are required to engage with the Session Zero to ensure that the game is appropriate for themselves, all players, and the keeper at the table.

Character Creation
Determining Character Stats
Cap on Starting Skill Values

No starting skill can be above 60% after modifications.

Rolling and Distributing Characteristics
For Caroline College, we use a variant of Option 3: Choosing Where to Place Rolled Characteristics.

Roll 6 × 3d6 and distribute the results across:

Strength (STR)
Constitution (CON)
Dexterity (DEX)
Appearance (APP)
Power (POW)
Luck (LUCK)


Roll 3 × (2d6+6) and distribute the results across:

Size (SIZ)
Intelligence (INT)
Education (EDU)
Note on Skill Caps: To reflect the inexperience of college freshmen, the cap on starting skills is set at 60%. This ensures characters have room for noticeable growth throughout the campaign.



Occupation: College Student
All characters at Caroline College use the occupation College Student.

Occupation Skill Points: EDU × 3 (Reduced from the standard to reflect starting students but with more opportunities for advancement during the campaign).
Credit Rating: 5–10
Suggested Contacts: Other students.
Skills:

Language (Own or Other)
Library Use
Listen
Three Fields of Study (choose three academic skills relevant to your character's studies)
Any Two Other Skills as personal or era specialties



Backstory Elements
Developing a rich backstory adds depth to your character and enhances the gaming experience. Each character should create entries for the following areas, aiming for meaningful and engaging content. This is a horror game, so dark elements within a backstory is acceptable, thematically appropriate, and strongly encouraged (within the limits defined by Session Zero). Try to remember that your characters don't know what's happening in the setting yet; hints and suggestions go a long way!
Ideology/Beliefs

Bad Example: "I believe in justice."

Why it's bad: Too vague and generic; lacks depth.


Acceptable Example: "I believe that the legal system is flawed, and true justice can only be achieved outside of it."

Why it's acceptable: Adds complexity and hints at potential conflicts.


Good Example: "Ethan prowls the city's backstreets at night, where justice rarely reaches. When the courts failed him and the guilty walked free, he wasn't above bending the rules to set things right. To him, the law is just a guideline, and true justice sometimes requires a darker path that others might deem questionable."

Why it's good: Provides depth, aligns with game themes, and introduces moral ambiguity.



Significant People

Bad Example: "My mother."

Why it's bad: Too general; doesn't explain significance.


Acceptable Example: "My mother, who supported my academic pursuits."

Why it's acceptable: Offers context but lacks depth.


Good Example: "Amelia carries a tattered letter from her estranged mother, filled with unsent words of apology. She reads it under dim lamplight, wondering about the life her mother chose over her family. Each word fuels Amelia's resolve to find her, not just to reconnect, but to understand the choices that led them apart."

Why it's good: Adds personal stakes, urgency, and ties to potential plot lines.



Meaningful Locations

Bad Example: "The park."

Why it's bad: Too vague; lacks meaningful context.


Acceptable Example: "The old park near my childhood home where I used to play."

Why it's acceptable: Provides some context but lacks depth.


Good Example: "The rusted remains of the old Ferris wheel loom over the deserted fairground, a place where Lucas once shared a fleeting moment of joy with his first love before she moved away without a word. He returns there, the silence heavy with memories and unanswered questions, hoping one day to recapture that lost connection or at least find closure."

Why it's good: Rich atmosphere, ties into supernatural elements, and profoundly impacts the character.



Treasured Possessions

Bad Example: "A book."

Why it's bad: Generic; doesn't reveal anything about the character.


Acceptable Example: "An old diary from my grandmother."

Why it's acceptable: Provides a familial connection but could be more detailed.


Good Example: "Lily discovered an old, leather-bound book hidden behind a loose brick in her grandmother's fireplace. The pages are filled with faded handwriting and strange symbols she doesn't understand. As she reads, unsettling family secrets begin to surface—stories of forgotten ancestors and choices that cast long shadows over her family's history, secrets they had tried desperately to keep buried. At least she knows she isn't alone in her bad choices."

Why it's good: Deeply personal, tied to game lore, and serves as a catalyst for adventures.




Balancing Classes and Investigations
Class Selection
Players must balance academic responsibilities with their mystery-solving adventures.

Each Semester, players must choose 5 classes.

Freshman Fall Semester:

3 Required Classes:

One Science
One History
One Language


2 Optional Classes:

Chosen from the list of electives.



Passing a Class
To pass a class, players must:

Pass the Final Exam:
- Involves making an advancement roll in the relevant topic.

Luck may be used on this roll.


Optionally, Meet the Attendance Requirement:
- Attend at least 70% of the class sessions (determined narratively).

Meeting attendance grants a +5% bonus to the relevant skill (in addition to advancements from exams).



Exams

Mid-Term and Final Exams will be held each semester.
Passing the Mid-Term:

Grants a Penalty Die on the final exam advancement roll.
Note: In advancement rolls, a failed roll results in skill improvement. Therefore, the Penalty Die increases your chance to fail the roll, which benefits your skill advancement.


Failing a Class:

If you fail the final exam but met the attendance requirement, you still gain the +5% bonus.



Tension Mechanic
Players must choose between attending classes or pursuing adventures, balancing academic success with their investigations.

Skipping Classes may lead to:

Falling grades.
Loss of skill advancement opportunities.
Potential narrative consequences.


Benefits of Academic Success:

At the keeper's discretion, and at thematically appropriate times, academic achievements may grant benefits.
Example: Passing all exams in a semester might unlock access to exclusive resources, faculty support, or special permissions.




Mechanics Adjustments
Sanity Loss Adjustments

Reading Mythos Tomes:

Costs sanity but will not trigger bouts of madness or insanity if done in a safe environment.



Recovery from Indefinite Insanity
Students at Caroline College have access to counseling sessions provided by the local Lutheran church. These sessions are non-religious and aim to aid students in recovering from indefinite insanity and trauma.

Weekly Counseling Sessions:

Availability: Once per week when not participating in a game session.
Sanity Recovery Mechanics:

Recovery Attempt:

Roll percentile dice (1d100).
On a result of 01–95:

Success: Recover 1d10 Sanity Points.


On a result of 96–100:

Setback:

Lose 1d6 Sanity Points.
Gain a new phobia related to the stress or topics discussed during counseling.






Resolving Indefinite Insanity:

If Sanity Points are gained during a counseling session, you may immediately make a Sanity check (using your updated Sanity score).
On a Hard Success, your indefinite insanity is resolved.




Time Commitment:

Attending a counseling session requires an in-game time slot, potentially conflicting with classes or investigations.


Keeper's Note:

Frequent therapy sessions may draw attention or have narrative implications, adding to the tension of balancing time.
Failed Therapy Sessions:

May induce phobias related to the therapy content, providing additional story hooks.







Luck Recovery and Advancement
Luck advancements are made at the start of every game session.

Luck Recovery Mechanics:

Improvement Check:

Roll 1d100.
If the roll is above your current Luck, add 1d10 points.
If the roll is equal to or less than your current Luck, no points are recovered.




Note:

Luck may not exceed 99.
The starting Luck value is not used again in the game.



Skill Advancements
Skill advancements are made after thematically appropriate breaks, as determined by the keeper (expect 3–5 per semester, including exams).
PvP Interactions and Loss of Control

Player vs. Player (PvP) 'Attacks':

Must be made with consent of all involved players.


Loss of Control Situations:

Occur when a character is under the effects of insanity, a Breakdown due to Distress, or certain supernatural influences.
Actions are at the keeper's discretion.
The keeper should consider player enjoyment and strive for consensual storytelling.



Backstory Connections

Robust and Thematically Appropriate Backstories:

Include one or more entries with a dark element.
Develop meaningful locations, significant people, and pivotal events that add depth.


Character Connections:

Every character must have a connection to at least two other characters in the party in their backstory.
No character can have more than two connections to them.



Group Skill Checks

Assisting with Skill Rolls:

If more than one character attempts a skill roll for the same task, under pressure:

If at least two characters have skill above baseline, one person can make the roll with a Bonus Die.





Spending Luck

Luck Points can be spent to alter the result of a skill or characteristic roll on a 1-for-1 basis.
Restrictions:

Cannot spend Luck on:

Luck rolls
Damage rolls
Sanity rolls
Rolls to determine the amount of Sanity points lost


Cannot spend Luck on Pushed Rolls.
Criticals, Fumbles, and Firearm Malfunctions cannot be altered with Luck.
No skill improvement check is earned if Luck was used to alter the roll.




Expanded Sanity Rules
These OPTIONAL rules add psychological realism to the Sanity mechanics, fitting for modern or historical settings where characters may be hardy and accustomed to man-made horrors. Their inclusion will be discussed during Session Zero.
See Optional Rules - Distress Points (DSP)

Session Zero Guidelines
Starting Campaigns
We begin new campaigns with a Session Zero to:

Align expectations.
Discuss boundaries.
Establish the tone.
Integrate characters into the world.

Backstories

Characters Should Not Start as Heroes:

Focus on backstories that plant seeds for future adventures.
Avoid having characters who have already achieved greatness.



Fitting the Tone

Ensure your character fits the theme of the campaign (early 1980's horror sit in small town America).

Party Dynamics

Create Characters That Fit the Party:

Develop strong connections with at least two other characters.
Collaborate during character creation to ensure cohesion.
Come to session zero with ideas, not characters.



Respecting the Mood

Maintain Immersion:

Avoid breaking tension with out-of-place jokes, side talk, etc..
Engage with the core themes agreed upon.



Rule of Cool

Story Over Rules: We'll follow the Rule of Cool to prioritize narrative over strict rule adherence.

Improvisation and Player Agency

Your Actions Shape the Story:

Major events occur based on your decisions.
Creativity is rewarded, even if payoffs aren't immediate.
Not every encounter is balanced; sometimes avoiding conflict is wise.



Player Preparation

Stay Engaged:

Be attentive during sessions.
Review notes between sessions.
Keep your character curious and involved.


Session Recaps:

Before each session, a player provides a recap of the previous session (group's choosing).
Incentive:

The player who provides the recap gains a one-time Bonus Die for the session (unused bonus dice do not roll over).





Safety Tools

Player Comfort Is a Priority:

Session Zero: Establish comfort levels and boundaries.
Lines & Veils:

Lines: Hard limits not to be crossed.
Veils: Topics that can occur but not be spotlighted.


X Card:

Tap the X card to immediately stop and change uncomfortable content.


Consent Flowers:

Green: Keep going.
Yellow: Proceed with caution.
Red: Change the subject.




Examples:

A player indicating a yellow consent flower might prompt the keeper to adjust the scene's intensity without disrupting gameplay.



Themes and Boundaries

Discuss Sensitive Topics:

Be proactive in expressing preferences.
Common topics include violence, discrimination, sexuality, and personal phobias.



Conflict Resolution

In-Character Conflict:

Should serve the narrative.
Avoid actions that disrupt group dynamics.


Out-of-Character Conflict:

Address issues respectfully among yourselves.
The keeper is a storyteller, not a mediator.



Role-Playing

Immerse Yourself:

Act and speak as your character.
Avoid phrases like "My character does X."



Player Respect

Treat Each Other with Respect:

Respect beliefs and views without imposing them.
Create a welcoming environment.
Address discomfort promptly and respectfully.




Common Topics to Discuss
During Session Zero, we'll address the following possible story elements to ensure everyone's comfort:

Frequently Lined Topics:

Sexualized violence
Child abuse
Animal cruelty


Frequently Veiled Topics:

Racism
Discrimination against minorities
Sexuality
Torture
Phobias (spiders, snakes, clowns, dentists)
Serious illnesses
Sexism
Suicide




By adhering to these house rules and guidelines, we aim to create an engaging, immersive, and enjoyable gaming experience for everyone involved. Let's work together to weave a memorable story set in the mysterious world of Caroline College.

Clubs and Societies
Below are 20 clubs and societies with you might engage with in and around the college. Each includes associated Call of Cthulhu skills.

Great Lakes Archaeological Society

Skills: Archaeology, History
Story Hooks: Discovering Native American artifacts linked to ancient rituals; uncovering local historical sites.


Caroline College Debate Club

Skills: Persuade, Fast Talk
Story Hooks: Debating controversial topics that stir up hidden tensions; uncovering faculty secrets.


Peach Street Library Occult Studies Group

Skills: Occult, Library Use
Story Hooks: Access to obscure local folklore; accidental involvement with real supernatural forces.


Folklore and Mythology Circle

Skills: Anthropology, History
Story Hooks: Exploring regional legends; finding connections between myths and current strange occurrences.


Caroline Science Association

Skills: Science (choose one), Mechanical Repair
Story Hooks: Experiments affected by mysterious phenomena; encountering anomalies in nature.


Literary Appreciation Society

Skills: Language (Own or Other), Art/Craft (Literature)
Story Hooks: Uncovering hidden messages in classic literature; meeting reclusive authors with dark secrets.


Psychology and Wellness Club

Skills: Psychology, Psychoanalysis
Story Hooks: Exploring the minds of troubled students; encountering mind-altering experiences.


Outdoor Adventure Club

Skills: Navigate, Survival
Story Hooks: Organizing trips into the nearby forests; discovering hidden places and strange happenings.


Thespian Troupe of Caroline

Skills: Acting, Disguise

Photography and Journalism Society

Our Earth Group

Skills: Biology, Survival
Story Hooks: Protecting local environments leads to strange discoveries; nature behaving unpredictably.
Keeper's Note: Involvement in clubs can provide:




Skill Bonuses: Gain a +5% bonus to associated skills while active in the club.
Story Opportunities: Clubs can introduce unique quests, NPCs, and resources.
Potential Risks: Groups can grant mechanical benefits as well as possible contacts. But some clubs may be fronts for groups your character may not wish to draw attention from.


By incorporating these elements, we aim to enrich the gameplay experience, providing ample opportunities for character development, fun, and immersive storytelling.

Gaming-Thoughts/How-I-Play.title: Welcome To My Table - A Guide For Players Looking To Play At A Table With Me
Gaming-Thoughts/How-I-Play.content:
Welcome to my table: A Guide For New Players Looking To Play At A Table With Me
What is this
This document is living and will be adjusted as my views grow and change. I have gamed for many decades and the only constant I have seen is change.
The following are my ideas and are focused mainly on players who have never played with me before. Your ideas about games and how they should be played may differ and that's great! The hope with this document is to see if we are compatible with each in terms of gaming. I believe strongly in the idea that not every table is right for every person.
Introduction
Role-playing games are for everyone, but not every game table is the right fit for every player. My goal is to create collaborative stories, where everyone helps drive the narrative. We all work together to build a fun and memorable experience. Below is a guide to help you understand the expectations and style of games I run.
Session Zero
We will always begin new campaigns with a Session Zero to align expectations, discuss boundaries, and establish the tone. There are two types of session zeros:


Established World: If we are playing in a defined setting, I will provide information about the world and its tone ahead of time. During Session Zero, we’ll discuss how your character fits into this world and make sure everyone is aligned on tone and boundaries. There is still a lot of flexibility available to us to tweak existing worlds to taste.


New Campaign Setting: If we’re starting a new campaign world, we’ll collaboratively build the world together. This is your chance to influence the setting, tone, and major elements. Be ready to share your ideas and preferences, so we can create a world that fits your expectations.


Character Creation
Character creation is a crucial part of any game, and we’ll handle this during Session Zero. Here’s what to keep in mind:

Backstories: Characters should not start as heroes; they are on the path to becoming heroes. Focus on creating backstories that plant seeds for future adventures, rather than ones where your character has already achieved greatness. Try not to come to the table with concrete notions about a character. The best characters are created within the context of a party.
Fitting the Tone: Your character should fit the theme of the campaign. If we’re playing a gritty, combat-heavy game, a pacifist may not work. If the game is about exploration, make sure your character is ready to explore.
Party Dynamics: We are playing games with a party, not individuals. Try to make a character that is interesting to you and fits in with the party. One way of doing this is making sure that your characters has a strong connection to at least one other character in the party.
'Evil' Characters: If you’re playing a morally gray character, ensure there is something that keeps you tied to the party. Conflicts within the party are fine if they create story opportunities but avoid actions that ruin the game for other players. And don't be surprised that actions have consequences. Murder hobos become the target for another party's quest.

Respecting the Mood
Mood is everything! Respecting the tone and mood of the game is important. Avoid breaking tension or stepping outside the genre we’ve agreed upon. For example:

Cracking jokes during an emotional scene can spoil the immersion.
Refusing to engage with core themes, such as exploration or combat, might disrupt the game.


Even hobbits go on adventures!

We’re here to build a story together, and maintaining the right tone helps everyone stay immersed.
House Rules and Rule of Cool
I follow the Rule of Cool—the story always comes before the rules. While we’ll try to follow the game system's rule, if strict rule-following slows down the game or takes away from the story, we’ll prioritize the narrative.

House Rules: These are generally aimed at speeding up gameplay or making things run smoother. For example, detailed combat rules might be simplified to keep the story moving.
Rules Lawyers: If you enjoy debating game mechanics, my games may not be the best fit for you. I prefer to focus on storytelling and improvisation. If you must debate the rules, with people that enjoy that type of thing, do so AFTER the session.

Improvisation and Player Agency
My games involve a lot of improvisation. Your actions will heavily influence the story’s direction, and major events will only occur if the antagonists can counter your actions. It’s entirely possible for you to derail or even prevent major, planned events through clever choices. I write stories based on plans and locations, not end goals. So if you are looking to 'win' a story then I am not the storyteller for you.

Modules are inspiration, not recipes!

Creativity is always rewarded, even if the payoff isn’t immediate. Feel free to try unconventional actions—negotiating with an enemy, coming up with new uses for spells, or devising clever solutions to problems. While not every move will work as intended, it will always shape the story in meaningful ways.
Unless planned for during session zero, not every encounter is balanced. Sometimes the best choice is to not engage.
Player Preparation
To help keep the story flowing, here are a few tips:

Be Attentive: Stay engaged with the game, listen to other players, and make notes if needed.
Review Between Sessions: Before each session, review your notes to refresh yourself on the story and prepare for what’s ahead.
Stay Curious: Keep your character curious and involved in the world—ask questions, explore, and look for ways to engage with the narrative.

Safety Tools
Given the mature themes often present in my games, player safety is a top priority. I use tools such as the 'X' card and consent flowers to ensure everyone feels comfortable.


Session Zero: we will establish the comfort levels for different topics. This is a proactive step to ensure that everyone is playing the game we want to play. You have to speak up for your preferences to be respected.

Lines & Veils: Lines are hard limits that you do not want to see in the game, veils are things that can come up but you do not wish to have it in the spot light. These limits can apply differently for PCs and NPCs. It might be a hard limit, a line, for the PCs to commit murder, but not for an evil NPCs (thus giving a reason for the players to stop them!).



X Card: If at any time you feel uncomfortable with the content, you can tap the X card to indicate we need to stop and change the topic immediately. It’s a disruption, but your safety is more important than the flow of the game.


Consent 'Flowers': A more subtle tool, consent flowers let you indicate your comfort level with the game in a non-verbal manner. Items will be provided that can be place in front of you in order to communicate your current comfort level.

Green: You’re fine, keep going.
Yellow: Proceed with caution.
Red: Please change the subject or theme.



Consent Flowers can be thought of as precursors to the X card.
If possible, try to raise concerns during Session Zero. It helps me tailor the game, and it gives you the ability to consent to the story’s direction.
Always assume that people are acting in good faith. Most people do not want to harm someone else; mistakes can happen. The best solution is always open and proactive communication. Everyone at the table is human and misunderstandings can happen. So it is on each person to help your fellow table-mates if they begin to stray from the agreed upon limits.
Common Topics to Discuss
From www.dramadice.com/gm-tips/safety-tools-for-tabletop-rpgs/
Frequently 'Lined' Topics:

Sexualized violence
Child abuse
Animal cruelty

Frequently 'Veiled' Topics:

Racism
Discrimination against minorities
Sexuality in general
Torture
Spiders
Snakes
Clowns
Dentists
Serious illnesses
Sexism
Suicide

This should be a starting point for the conversation, not definitive check list. I will give my list at the end.
Themes and Boundaries
There are many topics that I do not care to hear about in real life; harm to marginalized groups, women, children, violence, religion, etc. However, in dramatic stories these topic frequently arise. This is true even for darker topics within the context of villains or evil NPCs. My hope is that players will act as the force to oppose these actions. But these are my preferences.
For backstories, especially in horror games, it’s okay to explore darker themes. Just be mindful of other players’ boundaries and the tone we’ve established. (Another reason not to come to the table with preconceived ideas about your characters.)
Conflict Resolution


In-Character Conflict: Conflict between characters can add to the story, but it should serve the narrative and not disrupt the group dynamic. Always consider how your character’s actions impact the party. Don't be that person. If it is 'what your character would do' then maybe that character doesn't fit the party.


Out-of-Character Conflict: I prefer not to get involved in out-of-character disputes unless I’m directly involved. I’m a storyteller, not a mediator. If conflicts arise, try to resolve them respectfully among yourselves.


Role-Playing
In my games, immersive role-playing is encouraged. Try to avoid saying “my character does X” or “my character says Y.” Instead, speak and act as your character. You don’t need to be a professional actor, but embracing the role will enhance the experience for everyone.
Player Respect
While our characters may clash and NPCs may engage in morally questionable behavior, it’s essential that players treat each other with respect. Regardless of the actions within the game, I expect players to:

Respect each other’s beliefs and views without pushing them onto others.
Create a welcoming environment where no player feels insulted, ignored, bullied, or made uncomfortable.

Disagreements about in-game decisions are natural, but they should never escalate into personal attacks. If an issue arises that makes you uncomfortable, please let me or another player know so we can address it.
We’re here to create a fun and immersive experience together, and that starts with mutual respect at the table.
Communication
If you need to reach me outside of the game, feel free to contact me via Discord or email. I’m always open to hearing feedback, answering questions, or discussing any concerns you might have.
Warnings About My Style

In real life, most people do not view themselves as 'bad'... even when they are demonstrably acting that way. People are great at rationalizing their actions. Many of my villains do that too! So morally gray NPCs are common.
Improv is big part of my style. I love seeing the story we make together. That does mean I tend to forget things like minor NPCs names that were made up on the spot. Player notes help players and storytellers alike!
I like to start each session with a player recapping the last session. This allows me to see things from the other side. If I didn't explain something well, or a clue was missed, or some action is taking on more importance in the players' minds then was intended, this helps me see that.
I like long running stories where one event bleeds into the next. So it is a challenge for me to do things episodically. I can do it, it just goes against my nature.
I have told stories for over 40 years. That means I have 40 years of bad habits, not that I know more than someone else. I am still surprised most times I sit down to play.
I am here to have fun. I hope you are too. We work together to make sure every reaches this goal.

My List of Lines and Veils
I am very flexible on my list. Within the context of a good story I can move a line to a veil and ignore a veil altogether. But as a starting point here is my list:
Lines

Graphic roleplaying of taboo topics such a torture, abuse of minors, and sexuality between PCs

I am very sex positive but I don't wish to be engaged in PCs erotica. If it comes up in a story, state the minimum and move on. Violence happens in a game, state the minimum and move on. Full on role-playing out such acts is a line for me.


Audio/Visual of people in pain or abused, especially children

In a story I can handle dark topics but I do not care to see or hear such things. This includes in audio props or visuals produced as props.



Veils

Gratuitous violence without a story reason
Abuse of minors or the non-consenting
Manipulation for the 'fun of it'

Bad guys do bad things, got it. Sometimes the details are needed for a clue but let's keep even that to a minimum.

Niisii/Intro-Niisii.title: The World Of Niisii
Niisii/Intro-Niisii.content:
What was and what will be Niisii?
Niisii is the world I have spend the most time on, and know the least about. This is because it started as one thing; something good. And that good thing got morphed into something else. This new thing was good but it was never 'right'. It was forced into being something it was not supposed to be. And because it wasn't fit for this new purpose it broke.
Let me explain.
No, there is too much. Let me sum up.
Niisii was built at the request of a group of adult friends who gamed. This group of friends engaged in alternative lifestyles and activities. They a small request. "Could we make a world where heteronormality and monogamy were NOT the default setting?"
My answer was Niisii.
Sexuality, like in the real world, was a driving force in the world. The game was not erotic, but it was mature. The themes were heavy and tried to be thoughtful. The quests had more to do with human desire and fault (regardless of the species) than McGuffins and loot.
Stories were told, laughs were bellowed and tears were shed.
The DM was doing his job.
But as it happens, within the group there was a tiff. Someone in the group felt slighted and the games stopped because we all felt bad. And like that, Niisii was put on a shelf.

Fast forward
Years and passed and a new group of friend have formed. And they wanted a homebrew world to play in. FR is fun and all but ....
'Sure! When do you want to start playing?'
Tonight!
Ok, it was a few days later. But with work and life, what difference was 30-40 hours going to make.
So I dusted off an old friend and unlikely heroes went off to find a missing librarian.
Niisii was always built to support multiple DMs; a measure of design went into the world so that different people had their own 'corners' of the world with just enough connections to make it feel 'whole'. So, for this group, I found an area where the lore was ignored and started to tell stories appropriate to this group.
And then it grew.
Slowly, what made Niisii, Niisii was being pushed out in favor of 'generica'. Every race had to make an appearance, the world was always coming to the end, and no one wanted to go questing for love or vanity.
Another +5 sword would do just nicely thank you.
And of course, whatever came out in the latest book by WotC had to be rolled in.
Stories were told, laughs were bellowed and tears were shed.
The DM was doing his job. :-D
And not just the starting DM. Other DMs joined. And they told their stories too.
And each story moved the world further away from its flavor. Mechanics, lore, limitations and options were stripped to make room for the latest suppliment.
Sure, there were are few that wanted see what this 'old' Niisii was like but what do you mean my elf would live as long as my current 5e character?
Niisii was generic.
Don't get me wrong, we had a lot of fun in this world. Hundreds of years of history, epic stories, and games where, no exaggeration, over 20 people playing together in person (remember that!) just share in the stories.
To be fair that was only two or three times.
....the average game night was over 12.
And the games happened multiple times a week.
Epic
But it wasn't Niisii.
It wasn't a world built where a group of lovely, good hearted perverts, could tell stories of love and betrayal. All in a world where they weren't the freaks. Where they weren't the ones who had to hide who or how they loved. Where they had representation. Their lore and stories were ... different. And when their lore got in the way, it was erased. Not added to. Erased.
But with that said, it was not the games played in Niisii, nor the people who played them, that was the problem.
It was me.
I led people into this wonderful garden of joy. They didn't want to be there. They just wanted to play games. And if this was the world they had, well they would make a home for themselves here. They plowed the ground so they could plant their seeds. They did the right thing for them.
If I hadn't of been lazy, I would have made a world fit for them. It would have been something... sturdy. Every garden can be full of joy and no better than another. Just grow the garden that fits you!
As it is, Niisii lays in shambles. It doesn't 'feel' right anymore; at least not to its father.
Am I teary eyed sometimes about a make believe world?
Yeah.
No.
No, not for the world. For the why, and the who, it was made for.
Will I 'fix' Niisii someday?
I don't know. I doubt it. But I am often wrong.
What I do know is that maybe I'm beginning to learn a lesson. Knowing when to build new gardens and when to tend the old ones is something I hope to get good at in the next 100-200 years. :-)
Then why is this here?
To remind me of my mantra.
Don't be lazy Randy

Terra-Mortuum/Intro-Terra.title: The World of Terra Mortuum
Terra-Mortuum/Intro-Terra.content:
"You had to go and learn for yourself, didn't you?"
A look of anger, panic and fear each fought to control his mother's face as she moved the hair from his ashen brow. Dobbin had seen each of these emotions overtake her before. His mother was nothing if not... excitable. OK, she was a lot excitable. But there was always some subtle tell; some sly hint that she wasn't truly angry or panicked or afraid. He always thought that she just liked making a scene. The over-the-top warnings, her cries of feigned fear when he got in a fight and her sobs over the dangers her 'stupid baby boy' faced in his trades was just her excuse to be heard.
This was different. There was no cocked smile or quick wink now. There was only raw emotion.
Time passed but he could not tell how long. As the young man's hands began to stiffen, and his vision clouded, he could just make out the tears that flowed down her face as she stood from where she was kneeling by his bed. She left his room quickly. As he tried to call out to her, tried to say he was sorry, only a wet grumble came from his throat. A mass fell from his mouth and his face began to twitch uncontrollably.
He was so cold. Cold and starving.

A lifetime later she returned. The raw emotion replaced with cold, sterile, determination. In one hand she held the family's felling axe. In the other, the Beams of God that usually stayed above the hearth.
As she knelt once more by his bed, she whispered.
"I am so sorry baby."
She choked back the tears and continued.
"How many tales did we tell you? How many warnings to stay out of the Northern Fields? We didn’t do enough."
The battle with her emotions was taking a turn as her words began to take on the wet, fluid sound of uncontrollable loss.
It was then that Dobbin realized he had been holding his breath. As he tried to fill his lungs with air he found no heady relief; no soothing of the burning in his chest.
His eyes went wide as his heart began to slow.
His muscles started to twitch and break the bones of his toes.
His ears felt like they have been stuffed full of dandelion seeds.
She never let go of the hand of his hand. Even as the flesh pulled away from his nail bed and his convulsions tore through him with enough strength to break her little finger she held fast. She had failed him before. The least she could do now was to be with him while he was still … her baby.
And then it stopped.
Like a candle snuffed out, the boy... the human … died. She freed her damaged hand and stood.
In her good hand she reached down and cradled the Beams of God and tried to remember the ‘Prayer of the Good Death’. Slowly the words came to mind.
"O Spirit, As Dobbin journeys through the Sheltered Route's serene domain, Let him find rest from his mortal travels."
As she started, so too did the transformation. The human had left and the gravling was arriving much sooner than expected. He had spent too long in their domain. The days she had hoped the family had to mourn was quickly turning into minutes of terror.
"Gu-Gu-Guarded him from the clutches of a sleepless second life, so his soul may bask in the dreams of everlasting night."
Never letting the sign of her family's faith slip from her good hand, she took up the axe in her broken one...just in case her prayer wasn't enough.
"In the Sheltered Route's Haven, let my little boy find reprieve,"
As the broken shell of her only son started to rise, she thought of her daughters. The pain in her hand as she gripped the handle for the blow made the last line tear from her mouth like storm.
"Where eternal rest he shall achieve."

index.title: 'That' Randy's Stuff
index.content:
f you were looking for me, congratulations YOU WON. If you weren't looing for me I have to wonder why you are here. Are lost? Do you need a grown-up to help you get home? I'll try to help but I gave up being a grown up a long time ago. I'm just an old man that likes to play games, make mediocre music and working on being a better person today than I was yesterday.
What you will find here are links to my

TTRPG gaming campaigns I tell stories in

I am a proud member of the Forever DM club, and I like it that way
You will find some information about my two current worlds

Terra Mortuum: A grim dark fantasy game about a future after a horrible mistake was made.
Caroline College: Welcome to Wisconsin. The year is 1983, the metal is loud and all the things go bump in the night.


And you'll find a little bit about how I play here . Not everyone is a good gaming match with everyone else and that's ok. Before I waste your time, see if we might vibe. Don't worry, I'm flexible.


Music I Make

I do not claim to be good. I make music for me and those who want to play with me. 


Photographs I make

I don't take pictures as often as I used to but I still love the craft.



Finally I guess a bit about me isn't a bad thing to add.

I'm happily married to my high school sweetheart. Its been over 3 decades now and I'm still enamored with her.
I have three grown children. Two I helped make, a son and a daughter, one who I gained when she married my son.
I write mathy-optimizey-codey-things for a living

Don't worry, I'm a trained professional and can use these types of professional terms safely.


I'm very liberal. And believe in love, peace, equality, sex positivity, education, reason and joy for all.
